text: Bottle @ home, split two ways. Blackish pour with a small head. Notes of dark roasted malts, balsamic vinegar, light acidic, oak, leather, musty with a pleasant tartness. Very good!

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2017 Rami Rami is drinking a Nightmare On Brett (Aged In Port Barrels) by Crooked Stave Artisan Beer Project at Saska KÄ™paRodzynki, sliwki, gruszki, melasa w aromacie, az dziwnie. Kwasnosc pod kontrola, slodkosc tez jest. Ciekawe i klasaOcena potraktowana skryptem do przeliczania ocen (uzgodnienie UT/RB).

Backlog, ocena przepisana z untappd, w ramach uzupeÅ‚niania profilu na ratebeer. Crooked Stave panel, 5 z 15. Wybitne. Lekka czekolada, wiÅ›nie, kwas, Å¼urawina, Å›liwki, czerwone wino... Kapitalne piwo.

(375ml bottle from Mikkeller Webshop) Pours extremely dark brown with a moderate off-white head that fades quickly leaving a little lace. Aroma of black currant, blackberry, vinous port notes, lemon, oak, musty funk, slightly acetic balsamic character, lightly toasted malts, maybe a little sweet cola. Flavour is moderately high acidic (lactic and balsamic vinegar), lots of vinous character, a mix of port and tart red wine, black currant, tart cherries, dry oak quality, rather tannic, subtle Brett, just a touch of toast and chocolate from the malt. Finish is fairly dry with a bit of pucker and a mineral quality to balance the tannins. Medium-full body, slightly oily, with very soft carbonation. Smooth integration of barrel, drinks very much like a wine all things considered. Nice sipper.
Brown, nice beige head, fruity aroma, brett, wood, chocolate, fun, fresh, sour flavor, lemony, chocolate, wood, whiskey, fun, vinous, pickled, great beer, medium+ bodied.

Has a tart berry aroma. Blackish color with a nice tan head. Flavor is tart with blackberry and winey notes.

Notes: Bottle at the Denver Rare Beer Tasting Â’15
Bottle - pours purple dark brown tan head ring - nose/taste of pinot, chocolate, funk, oak - medium body
Bottle. Dark pour with lighter head. Dark fruit, oak, port, wine and sweet aromas. Port wine, oak, tart fruit, light fruit tannins.

Bottle at Mikkeller & Friends, july 26th 2015. Dark brown body with a small beige head. Aroma is roasty with lactic elements, booze and dark sweet fruits. Taste is quite sour without peeling my teeth, rum, vanilla and berries. Mild citrus notes with a funky brett edge. Dry and acidic finish. A very nice Nightmare.
pour red brown with a light brown head. vinegar aroma, light liqurish, light port notes, lots of black current, taste SOUR SOUR SOUR, really nice black sour if you like extream sourness.

Bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with a small fizzy brown head. Aromas of vinegar, black currants, cherries, woody, oaky, cola, balsamico, light licorice. Taste is tart, vinegary, malty, oaky, vinous, vanilla, cherries, licorice, tannins. Pretty nice.

375 ml bottle shared by Drew. Pours a dark cola brown color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor have dark fruits, cherry, berries, tart, wood, Port character, vinous, some acidity, solid brew, dry, funk, seems to be more lacto character, solid drinker, interesting brew.

12.7oz bottle, thanks to Drew D. for sharing. Bottled July 2014. Awesome black cherry / blackberry in the nose. Clears my congested sinuses just from the smell. Vinous, dark red grape, touch of dark chocolate. Kind of a bigger sour taste, on the higher end of sour without being uncomfortable. Moderate bitter taste. Medium to bigger body. Kind of chewy. Lighter carbonation. Dark brown color. Thin off-white head. Loose bits of lace. A totally awesome sour. Nightmare on brett? Obviously, thereÂ’s way more than just brett here. Just awesome.

(375ml bottle) Pours a dark plum body with a small beige head. Aroma of caramel, roasted malt, oak, port, and dark fruit. Flavor of brown sugar, port, berries, oak, vinous, brett, and roasted malt with a dry finish.
Ratebeer Odense Summer Gathering 2015. Quite sour and funky character. Fruity notes

30-OCT-2015, bottle @UlklÃ¸bben meeting, @Sonni.
Dark amber with lasting tan head. port aroma, roast, coffee - very stoutÂ’sh. Tart, full, soft carbonation. Very strange but complex and very interesting.

375ml bottle shared at a tasting. The port nullifies the sour a little. Brown-burgundy body. Foamy beige head. Leathery toffee aroma. The sour comes back in the taste, oily. Unique oily brown US sour.

Bottle split at Mikkeller Viktoriagade, 30/04/15.
Light black with a well appointed tan covering formed of bubbles.
Nose is rich in brett, wood must, candied fruit, damp and musty, nutty, light spice, caramelised brown sugar, funky, a real treat of sourdom.
Taste comprises rich dark fruits, brett forward, spice, light charred notes, prune juice on the turn, wood must, funky, tarte red berries, subtle barrel and port licks.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with an honest bretty lick.
Xolid Xour ... lots of depth, drinks well below the ABV, great balance.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Pitch black - offwhite head. Sourness, wooden. dark fruits, roasted, rubber, acid, zesty, grapes, black currants, brett, lacto. Lovely.

Bottle. Thanks Tim. Aroma is great, fruity, bit of sourness, Brett, rich, maybe can get the port if I think if it. Taste is very nice, initial sourness, rich fruitiness, slightly nutty, blackcurrant, grapes. Finish is very fruity and long. No hint of the booze. Very nice.

Pours dark brown, not much foam. Aroma is very sour, didnÂ’t really expect that from the appearance. Dry dark fruits without much of a sweetness. Taste has acidity, feels light and surprisingly refreshing. Real treat.

Medium brown color, with red tinges around the edges. Light reddish brown head. Big Brett nose, with oak and port and a touch of baijou (Chinese liquor). The mouth is puckering, oak, port, wood, and tons of Brett. The depth is fantastic. Lingering port and oak finish and the sourness just stays. Wow.

Thanks to TimE for sharing the bottle!

Poured into a taster showing dark black center and coffee tinged rims; no head. 

The nose shows shrewd oak reminiscent of an Italian wine with slight hints of plums. High intensity and immediately noticeable. 

The palate is light bodied and moderately carbonated. Clean brett tartness tinged with the sweet port flavors and extremely slight hints of plum and cassis. Overall, this is incredible.

375ml bottle from Mikkeller webshop. Bottled July 2014. Pours dark red-brown in colour with a beige foam head. Nose of berry fruits, port, woody oak, funk. Taste is initially very sour, vinegar & citric rind, then funk, fruity notes, wood, oak, port and some dry bitterness. Fairly smooth underlying mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft carbonation, slightly woody but clean dry finish. Very drinkable.
Odense ratebeer summer gathering 2015.pours dark brown reddish. Aroma of sour berrys, tart. Funk, Brett. Taste grapes, funk, tart, sour, sweet. Extremely dry.
Bottle @ Odense Summer Gathering, 2015. Pours nearly black with a white bubbly head. Wood, blueberries, funk and oak. Tart , warming , prickly and soft.

375 ml bottle. July/2014. Courtesy of olio. Thanks!
Dark reddish brown color with a small tan head.
Brett, berries, dryness, sourness and some.... in the aroma.
The flavor is sourness, tartness, red berries, dryness and mild alcohol. 
I'm really missing the Portwine elements in this one. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

375 ml bottle.
Pours dark mahogany color with a small off-white head. Dark ripe fruits and berries on the nose, some earthiness too. Sour dark berry flavor, cocoa, yeast, some spices too. Could use some more subtleness, a bit harsh at times. All-in-all, quite impressive.
326

375ml bottle
Bottled July 2014 - Pours reddish black with a small brown head. Aroma of sour berries, funky yeast, oak, wood, vinous notes and syrup. Taste is heavy, sour and tart with some blackcurrant, wood, oak, syrup, toffee and funky yeastiness. Finish is heavy, strong and funky with some blackcurrant, bretta, sourness, oak, wood and berries. Pretty heavy but surprisingly well balanced.

07.07.2015, 0,375l bottle @ home:
Nice light brown slightly bubbly-creamy mediumlasting head. Aroma is slightly rich and sour-ish, dark malts, dark sour fruits, oak, grass, sorrel, soda powder, caramel, berry skin, licorice, dark sugar. Taste is sour-ish dry, oak, sorrel, sour dark fruits, dark malts, grass, soda powder, minerals, berry skin, caramel, dark sugar, coffee, licorice. Medium bitterness, sour-ish dry mouthfeel. Very nice!

Bottle 375ml.
Pours dark brown with low off-white head. Some lacing. Aroma is of porto, fruits. Taste is of acid, fruits, vinegar, flanderÂ’s brown-reminiscent features, porto. Palate: Medium-full bodied. Light carbonation. Overall: Good. A tad portoesque. Fruity. Sourness is under controll.

Bottle shared at a tasting at ArielÂ’s place. Dark brown to black with a beige head. Aroma is cellary, musty, oaky, vinous, with funk, fruitiness, vinegar. Sour flavor, cellary, funky, lactic, with wine, oak, cherries, some vinegar. Medium-bodied. Really good.

Bottle (375 ml). Shared by mathieuc, thanks!

Appearance: Dark brown with reddish notes, a small brown head and little lacing. 

Aroma: Port upfront along with dark fruits, chocolatey notes, grapes and earthy notes.

Taste: Moderately tart and acidic. Port forward with dark fruits, chocolate, roasted malt, earthy notes, grapes and a touch of alcohol,

Palate: Medium body. Medium carbonation. A bit vinous. Earthy and fruity finish. 

Overall: Not super complex, but some really nice port features. Way better and more balanced than the regular version we had before.

Bottle, bottled July/2014, enjoyed one year later. Pours dark brown, with a creamy mocha head settling to a small cap. Aroma is tart with balsamic vinegar, bretty notes of wood and flowers, and port barrels with dark fruits, berries and tobacco, as well as sweet notes of cherries and some alcohol. Medium body, with soft carbonation. Flavour is sour acidic balsamic vinegar, funky wooden brett, unripe fruits and lemons, as well as dark berries, wooden barrels and fruity notes of port. A bit too acidic, lacking a bit mellowness and complexity. Dry, acidic finish.

Pours a dark brown with no head but somehow there is still some lacing patterns on the glass. Nose is of grapes, coffee, light ash and light acetone. Taste is of grapes, coffee and ash. Vinous. Moderate body and carbonation. Overall this wasnÂ’t too different from the straight and just as enjoyable. Maybe a touch more ash in this one, though.

pours hazy dark brown, purple tint, with a reviving beige cap, nice lacing. roasted buttery spicy chocolate, red grapes, burnt toffee, plums, medium acidity, astringent wood, spices. light carbonation, medium body - oily; tart, woody and spicy finish. firmly tart with a pleasant spicy chocolate. nice port wine features.

Bottle shared. Deep black pour with thin cream colored foam. Aroma is nice, light earthy note, woody, roasty aromas with winey notes, quite fruity, plums. Taste is lightly tart, light acetic, roasty, winey notes. Palate is med bodied with light carbonation. Better than the Leopold whisky version.
Very tasty stuff,with a grape finish. Boozy nose. Very smooth full mouthfeel and thick appearance. Masterful. Great drinkability.

Bottle 375ml. [ As Crooked Stave Nightmare on Brett (Port) ].Clear dark black brown color with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, sour - grapes, wine - red wine - port. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate acidic with a long duration, tart, roasted, grapes, wood, port notes. Body is medium, texture is oily to watery, carbonation is soft to flat. [20150430]
Bottle. Pours an almost black color with a small tan head. Has a fruity sour tart woody weak port aroma. Fruity sour tart woody port flavor. Has a fruity sour tar woody port finish.

Bottle @ Mikkeller Bar Victoriagade. Pours viscous black with a small bubbly mocha head that leaves lots of spotty trace on the glass while 

dissipating. Smell is malty, fruity and funky with roasted malts, caramel, dark bread, biscuits, lemon juice, leather, port wine, moist soil, 

moist wood, barnyard, grape skins and lemon zest. Taste is heavy sour, tiny bitter, slightly malty, slightly fruity and slightly funky. 

Mouthfeel is soft, slightly dry, tart, tiny astringent and medium bodied. Finish is sour with roasted malts, burnt caramel, lemon juice, 

raisins, moist soil, hay, minerals, barnyard, elather, moist wood and lemon zest. Kinda cool but a bit too sour and fairly hard to drink...

375mL bottle, pours a deep dark mahogany with a tiny head of beige bubbles. Aroma is fairly subtle, with notes of toasted sesame seeds and light dry port barrels. Flavour is medium sour, with a good amount of acetone, with tart dry dark fruits and light vinous port barrels. Quite intensely sour after a while, with the acetic notes becoming more pronounced as well. Cohesive and well-structured, but a little harsh. Good.

Pour out of 375 ml bottle, dark black pour with off white head, aroma brought notes of dark cherry, berry, some oak, vanilla, slight earthy notes into tart lemon, slight grape. Taste was a mix of lemon, oak, wine into slight chocolate, dark fruit, slight berry, finishing tart.
37.5 cl bottle. Pours hazy dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is toasted dark malty. Fruity. Citric and tart. Roasted. Dry. Citric. Toasted malty. Lingering fruity finish.
From bottle at Mikkeller bar, Viktoriagade. Black with a biege head. Aroma and flavour of yeast, sourness, oak, malt and port.

30th April 2015Bigger Copenhagen bimble with Colin, Ronnie, Reuben and Alex. Mikkeller Vik. Bottle share with the Swedish drinking team. Opaque black - brown beer, bubbly pale tan head. Palate is semi dry with mild fine carbonation. Tangy and thing dark malts, turns mildly sour. Little wood in the mid. Mild Port and itÂ’s accompanying berry fruits. Light dry finish brings a little spice. Hides the abv pretty well.
Very complex and very tasty. The finish is very well done on this one. Great port and tannin sh!t gong on.

Bottles at Fredfest. Pours a black hue with a small beige head. A big sweet port with sour funky tones. The overall flavor is a battle between these two with sweet port notes and malty goodness winning I think, but very vinous, dark sour cherries. Damn good beer.

Bottle. Hazy amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, dark fruits, yeast, brett and lemon. Flavour is malt, fruit, dark fruits, oak, brett, port wine, lemon, sour fruit, sour and medium dry.
From bottle at Fredfest. Pours near black with a nice tan head and a sour malt aroma. There is a full-bodied roasted malt and dark molasses flavor with a lot of dark sour fruit. Delicious and tart.

Bottle @ Mikkeller bar, Victoria gade. Pours black with a brown head. Aroma of light sourness, yeast, oak, tart fruit, little sweet, little rum. Flavor is light sour, light sweet, yeasty, wood, tart fruit, oak, dark fruits. Thin to medium body, average carbonation, acidic finish. 300415

Tap. Deep brown body with a small beige head. Aroma of wood, funk, citrus, vanilla, black currant and yeast. Slightly sweet flavor that ends up dry and tart. Medium bodied watery to oily texture and soft carbonation. A very nice Sour indeed. ðŸŒŸðŸŒŸðŸŒŸðŸŒŸ

Aromas of roasted sour malts and fruits. Hints of port
Taste has nice port wineish, sour green apples, bretta

Pours black with almost no head. Aromas of funk, blackberry, brett, black currant, citrus. Taste s blackberry, black currant, funk, roasted oak notes, citrus. Mouthfeel is quite thin with low carbonation.
Pours dark brown to black with minimal light tan head. Aroma of bretta, blackcurrant, port. Taste is rich fruit tarty with balanced sweetish finish. Body is light and smooth with average carbonation.
Bottle @ Mikkeller, Viktoriagade. Clear dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel and sour fruit. Flavor is quite sweet and light acidic. Dry and light acidic finish. 300415

Bottle [emailÂ protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Bar, Copenhagen - dark brown almost black. Aroma and taste is berry fruity, delicate and subtle fruits, clean on the palate, nice balance, beautiful.

---Sent via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at Mikkeller Bar Viktoriagade. Black beer witha nice beige/brownish head. Sourish vinous aroma, roasted, leather, herbal, grassy, brett, spicy notes. Huge sour vinous brett flavor, floral, dandelions, grapefruit notes, some leather and vinegar. Quite nice.

Bottle to snifter (shared with the Mrs; thanks Dogbones). Looks good a very cloudy dark amberish brown with very light beige head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells and tastes tart and malty with notes of oak and cherry. Mouthfeel is medium-bodied. Good beer.

375ml bottle pours dark brown black with a finger of foamy head. Nose has dusty chocolate spice, ashy grape, dark berry, vinous fruit, light roast, dark toast. Taste is sweet with mixed vinous dark berry, funk, and sweet bitter dusty cocoa spice, dark chocolate, toasted oak, blackberry. Finishes sweet with a continuation of the palate and some lip smacking vinous chocolate covered mixed berry.

Bottle thanks to who else pReziDent NielZ ! Pours deep burnt umber with some rusty edges and a finger of khaki foam. Tons of layers of dark fruit, lots of port influence, nuances of cocoa powder, heavy roast and wet funky wood thorughout ! Delicious !
Bottle - Woody, dark malts and some dark Berry notes. Deep black brown with. A decent light brown head. Deep dark soured malts and lots of wood with some Berry notes.

375ml bottle courtesy of Reserve Membership. Assist via Mr. Nielsen. Thanks, bro. Finally coming full circle with the Nightmare series. Pours a deeper blacihs brown hue, a healthy hazed body with brownish red glow and plum, dark fruit colors shooting to the edges and bottom. Frothy light brown head sits atop, a decent layer dies to a thicker ring, nice enough lacing overall. Aromas show big dark fruit, pulpy blackberry and red wine meet tart and fleshy plum, tannic and oak and deep red wine. Dark fruit, earth, lactic pop is sour and lactic, a bit toasty and biscuity. Raisin, plum and prune meet those fleshy red grapes, some tannic grapeskin and earth, mellow funk elements. Initial is medium bodied, a bit slick and sour with distinct toasty elements, touches of balsamic and firmer oak. Sour plum and dark fruit, touches of blakc cherry, blackberry and red wine. Jabs of vanillin, oak, fruity dark depth is quite alluring. Yogurty life, tannic elements and sour twang comes in and out. A bit of gentle acidity, deep red wine, black cherry and plum. Really lovely stuff. Backend is funky, a bit dry and tannic. Plum and prune, cherry and red wine with that firmer lactic twangy feel on the backend, sufficient solid sourness with firm yogurt, a bit of toast and faint cocoa elements peeking through. Red wine, Port and earth meet some red grape, subtle biscuit and funk linger on. The oak integrates well and the richer lush dark fruit presence is complex and sour but not overdone not sweet and a bit brooding/underdone as some younger offerings can be. Lovely stuff, I think I enjoy this one the most from this series. The complex and deeper Port elements seem to integrate well, the fruit elements and sourness are on point. The more recent ones (Whiskey, Port) certainly seem like theyÂ’ve come a long way compared to eaerlier barrels.

Bottle - Pours rosy cola color with a ring of tan head. Nose is black cherry and lots of bready malt. Taste is real bready, with dark cherry, a little tartness, and a bit of chocolatey malt. I donÂ’t really get the port, and thatÂ’s disappointing. Medium bodied and slick, well-carbonated.

Bottle shared with annie and Al, pours purple darkness with small off white head. Notes are sour and tart with just the right amount of roast. Medium bodied. Notes of sour cherry, cocoa, Brett, lemon skin, port, old ale, and currants. Really nice.

Bottle... This beer rocks!... Pours murky and dark brown with flickers of purple and a small, creamy, taupe head. The nose is fruity and vinous, featuring red wine, dark berries and a modest measure of roastiness. Medium-bodied with prickly carbonation. The flavor is sour, fruity and seedy with lightly coarse and mildly bitter berry-skin tannins. Finishes tangy, fruity and lightly roasty. A world class beer generously provided by landhoney!

Bottle to glass. Pours a deep brown to black color with a thin rim of tan head. Aroma is slightly tart, sweet, port. Flavor has a good oily sour with a sweet boozy finish. Just had the grand cru right before this and it is an entirely different beer. Both delicious, but this one has a bit less sour.

Murky brown color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of char, dark fruits, wild yeast, bacteria, vanilla, port. Taste of dried fruits, vanilla, port, dark malts, and a sour finish.

Bottle thanks to Felipe! Pours dark mahogany, small tan head, some lacing. Aroma is funky funky funky, oaky, vinous. Flavor is medium tart, light plus funk, basement and Brett, bit of roastiness, lots of vinous notes, port or red wine. Medium body.
Dark dark brown. Funky sour cherry and cocoa. Very tart cherry flavor, light roast, some funkiness.

Bottle, 1/5/2015. Pours black, thin tan head fades to splotchy wisps on the surface. Aroma of earthy dark roast and chocolate, mild coffee grounds, vanilla in the middle leading to fruity grape and berry notes, port, wood and funk. Taste is chocolate, tart grape and dark fruit, more fruity oak and vanilla with vinegar tang in the finish. Medium body, thick and almost creamy as it warms. Quite tasty.

Tap at the brewery; GABF weekend, 2014. On my second visit to the brewery, the Sunday after the festival. Black. Strong port aroma and also a lot of it in the flavor, but it does not have the sugar found in most port. Some earthiness; yeast, and a little tart. Also some berry flavor in the finish.

On tap @ Beachwood Brewing. Just about black in color with a khaki head. Nose is rather fruity and almost jammy. A lot of vanilla, grape jelly, and sweet wine. Still, very assertive vinegar aromas. Some hints of vanilla, chocolate, and roasted malt. This is very tannic and sour. Dry as well. Lots of balsamic and red wine vinegar. Sticky jam and port. Tons of grape, berry, and plum. Somewhat malty with some chocolate.

Bottle @ home from the Crooked Stave Reserve Society. Pours a deep black appearance with a thin dark brown head. Blackberry, dark grape, roast, light coffee, a bit of smoke, and tart fruits in the nose. Medium full body. Some yogurt, dark fruit, fig, tart grapes, wine in the flavor. Moderate acidity. ThereÂ’s some roast and burnt notes as well. This is pretty dang nice.

375 ml bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a small lingering tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, port, citrus, light oak and light coffee. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a dry tart finish. Flavors of roasted malt, coffee, port, citrus, oak and a hint of vanilla with a crisp dry tart lingering roasty port finish.

Pour is black with small amount of light brown head. Nose is lightly roasted malt, a bit of marshmallow, leathery brett, and a hint of vanilla and wood. Taste is extremely sweet, roasted malts are faint, some marshmallow, huge malt sweetness, really overtakes things. A fair bit of bitterness, light acidity in finish. Palate is a bit slick, moderate carb, bitterness lingers through the finish.

Bottle via trade. Pours almost black with no head. Aromas of dark fruit, some light unidentifiable berries. Taste is tart and semi dry. Flavors of sour grapes, wine, some Brett funk, some yogurt. All of this and yet it feels quite thin and lacking something. Finishes tart and slightly acidic. Pretty good, not world class.

Aroma has a light roast and dark malt character with quite a bit of dark fruit, berry and cassis mostly but also cherry and plum. Moderate port notes with hints of alcohol. 
Pours a dark brown with lighter brown notes on the edges and a small, tan, head that quickly receded to the edges where it lingered for a bit. Light lacing and small legs. 
Flavor is moderately acidic with a light dark malt character. Moderate dark fruit notes with a light vanilla character. Medium light bitterness and moderate port character. Some light alcohol spice in the finish. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, a nice dark sour, but still not a style I like. Nice port character with lots of dark fruit notes.

On tap at The Source. Aroma: red wine, light oak, sweet port. Palate: light body, soft carbonation, dry finish, oily. Taste: merlot on the front, into a nice tartness. Overall, I want a bit more tartness out of this beer. Not my favorite for a port beer.
(375ml bottle) clear dark beer, fine tan bubbles. Nose of dark malt, dark fruit, light acid, vinegar, berry, a bit over the top. Taste is vinegary, dark malt, tart dark fruit, figgy, neat finish.

Sample at The Source. Pours nearly black with a bit of ruby around the edges. Medium light beige head that dissipates steadily to a film, and strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of vinous oak, yeast and malt. Medium to full body with flavors of port wine, oak and chocolate malt. The finish is tart with a port wine and oak aftertaste. Solid beer all around.

Sophisticated. Sour fruit esters with wood essence. Dark brown like a port. Smooth and full palate with mild carbonation. Sour up front that moved to an oak and port character. Somewhat dry. A lot going on with a lingering sourness.
Tap. Pours black with tan head. Aroma is roasty, chocolate, sweet, figs, sour. Taste is sour, chocolate, good carbonation, medium sour, medium bodied. Overall, fantastic.

Poured from tap to glass. Murky reddish brown hue with tan head that settled. Aroma is lactic, wood, grapes, sugar, straw. Mouthfeel is great with a medium body and crisp carbonation. Taste is dry sweetness followed by a great tart sourness and a clean finish. Overall this is a great beer.

375ml bottle in a Cellar Reserve glass. Pours near black with a lacy, beige head. Aroma of light sourness and funk on the nose, port wine and oak, dark malts with roast and dark chocolate and hints of coffee, and notes of dark fruits. Flavor an incredible blend of the sour and funk and dark beer and port barrels. Average to smoother texture. A really good and very unique beer.

Aroma: Currants, Red Plum, Mild Port

Appearance: Dark Brown Hue, Passes Almost No Light, Brown Head Ring, Some Lacing

Taste: Red Plums, Bitter Red Wine, Red Grape

Mouthfeel: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Mildly Drying, Mildly Bitter

The beer is pretty much black. Maybe just a bit of dark maroonish brown at the edges. A small amount of tan bubbles on top. Mostly dissipates after a minute. The aroma is big on vinous barrel character. Solid oak. Lots of fruit. Besides grapes, there are apricot, blackberry, plum, cherry and other fruit complexity. Good stuff. Earthy funk. Some gentle caramel sweetness and a light treacle background. The taste is mildly to moderately sour. Fruity and funky. Very little roast flavor, which I like - maybe, some extra fruitiness but itÂ’s mixed in with everything else. Good oak. Very tasty beer. I was a bit worried about it being a dark sour, but thereÂ’s not much dark malt character to it. Tasty.

Bottle thanks to Tom. Pours a dark brown with small off white head that dimibishes to nothing. The aroma is strong port, oak, and roast. Medium mouthfeel with strong port, funk, vinegar, roast. Hides alcohol well, very good.

Bottle at home with my wife. Pour is deep brown with a small tan head that quickly dissipated. Caramelized grapes, brown sugar, oaky, some tannins, black currants and cherries in the aroma. Taste is deep grapes, tang, heavy oak, caramel, port notes, and pears with a lighty sour finish. Medium body with high carbonation. One of the better versions of Nightmare for sure.

Dark brown pour, tan head. This may be my favorite in the series to this point. The port barrels have muted some if the flavors that, at times, I find unpleasant in dark sours. A good dose of sour funk, rich balsamic, roasted malt, port, and molasses.

Cellar Reserve Bottle enjoyed @ 45F split 2 ways in stemware. 

A - Pours nearly black out of the bottle, pitch black with a reddish hue on the glass. 2 finger sticky espresso head which fades slowly to some sticky ring.

S - Nose is very nice! Big grape, raspberry tart dry oaky aroma. Smells just wonderful. ThereÂ’s a touch of roast...like a Port Barrel Tart of Darkness

T - This is a nice beer. Start tart and sweet with a lot of oak. Middle is merlot grape, oak and obvious sweet port. Roasted burnt wood and some olive brine at the finish. Port then sticks around for quite a while.

M - sweet,. oily and boozy.
